Trade Update:

  1. eur/chf short: 1 lot closed at +50; 2nd lot is now at +39.

If this trade can get moving, there's some potential for a decent trade. The lows have been getting lower since 5/9. If you run a fib from 3/17 to the high, the trend line corresponds just about exactly with a 38.2% fib retracement. If you instead run the fib from 4/10 to the high, the trend line corresponds with the 61.8% fib retracement.   
  
Either way, that would bring us to a price of about 1.5975, which would be a cool 300 pips on this trade. Of course, it has a long way to go to hit that target, and both currencies really got clobbered against virtually all other currencies today, so it will be interesting to see if it drops.   
  
I don't see any new AshFX trades that I'm excited about, so it looks like eur/chf will be my only trade going into next week.

I think you're correct in every example you mentioned.  
  
Of the four trades you noted, two should never have been taken per AshFX rules. That includes the CHF/JPY trade you mentioned, as well as the AUD/CAD trade. Both were short signals, but each had a bullish signal candle, so neither trade was valid.  
  
If the stop loss rules for a Second Strength trade had been followed, the EUR/JPY trade would not have been stopped out just as you noted. The first lot would have closed at +97 and the second lot would now be about 190 pips up.  
  
The other trade you mentioned was the GBP/CHF short. However, this was never a signal on FXDD charts, which is what Ash recommends for this system ([http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost...&postcount=648](http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost.php?p=2088619&postcount=648)), so this trade also would not have been taken had that suggestion been heeded.  
  
This isn't meant to cast stones at airx3000 because it's easy to forget details in the heat of trading, but it does illustrate the importance of following the AshFX rules and recommendations to the letter for best results. In this case, it would have prevented some substantial losses.

You're asking about a specific company, and I know nothing about them, so I don't feel comfortable answering that question, adeforex.   
  
I will tell you my experience. I did not do well at all trading with pivot points. That doesn't mean there's not any merit to them; I just never felt confident using them. Other traders, conversely, swear by pivot points. You need to find the "shoe" that's comfortable for you. In other words, find a style of trading that fits you and that you will feel comfortable with.  
  
In regard to fib points, my suggestion to you would be to practice and observe how price reacts around the various fib lines, and then incorporate that into your trading style.  
  
In general, I do much better not relying on information provided by outside sources, but that's just my personal opinion. The things I look at in deciding on a trade are strong support and resistance areas, as well as fib and trend lines. I don't make it a lot more complicated than that.

Ok, this is my personal opinion. Others can mention theirs if they wish...   
  
£15k is decent is you're trading part-time and have a job. Heck, any amount is fine if you've got a job. (As long as you don't risk a large % of your equity on each trade of course.)  
  
If you want to quit work and trade full-time, FOR A LIVING, then I would recommend £20,000 initial capital. And this £20k has to be money you can afford to lose.   
  
3% risk is relatively high. Try to lower it to 2%.

GBPCHF I mentioned is not a valid signal. How can I go long or short?  
  
One needs to look at price action as a whole and look for the overall trend direction with S/R and when valid Ashfx signals present then enter the trade.  
  
_**S/R:**_ trendlines, S/R areas( Use weekly charts for daily charts and draw them ), fibonacci, pivots, 20,50,100,200sma/ema are all valid S/R .Whatever the individual trader feels comfortable !  
  
Do your analysis of price action on the higher timeframe and enter on the lower timeframe. Even exit on a timeframe lower than theone you entered.  
  
Many good exit strategies have been mentioned throughout the thread. A simple one is draw a trendline in the direction of the trade entered and exit when price breaks that trendline.  
  
Hope this helps.  
  
LR

I think you should test the system yourself. If you are thinking of trading the system live you will need the practice. I'm sure you don't want to trade real money on a system based on what other people say.   
  
I doubt you will find more than a couple of members that would agree 100% on every trade. (We may come to a consensus by discussing a trade on this thread) The rules look straight forward at first glance until you consider we take support and resistance into the trade decision. There can also be a different view on FS and SS trades. A cross on the stoch can look like a FS trade just viewing it. It can dictate a SS by a small amount if you use the data window to determine the stoch and signal level. Some members even use different brokers like Alpari or IBFX. They will end up with different trades and results. Perhaps with testing they may find a way to more profitable taking the signal from a broker with a day that starts closer to 00:00 GMT. I don't know. I use FXDD because it is the default broker the system was started on.  
  
It is important to trade the system in a way that has proved profitable to you in your forward testing.

If you are talking about the *.tpl file, that is a template file. It is used by MetaQuotes' Metatrader 4. It is a trading platform that is available for free as a demo platform.  
  
You do not open the *.tpl file. Just save it to your computer. Save it to the c:\program files\FXDD - Metatrader4\templates folder. Re-start the platform and right mouse click on your chart and select template and choose the file you saved. (This is one of several ways to apply a template.)  
  
The chart timer is an indicator file you would save it to the c:\program files\FXDD - Metatrader4\experts\indicators folder. You can attach it to the chart from the MT4 navigator window or other ways.  
  
Note: your folder name will vary if you do not use FXDD for your demo account or if you install the MT4 program to a non-standard directory.

Perfectly correct, They are all countertrend trades for the weekly TF. Being daily charts and most of these moves were large, these particular countertrends are expected to at least 38% retracement of the move. Even maybe 50% or 61.8% retracement.Therefore for the aggressive trader, these will translate into many pips.  
  
Some traders trade countertrends, others will trade lower timeframes eg. swingtraders will look at the daily charts for the trend and trade 1h/30m charts in the direction of the daily trend.  
  
It depends on the trading plan for the individual trader and the TF they choose to trade.  
  
Ashfx signals work best on daily TF but will translate to pips in the lower TF.  
  
Several traders use Ashfx as signals with other filters.  
LR

The PSAR does not re-paint.  
I'm not sure what broker's chart you are showing but it does not look like a new day has started. The psar dot can change back and forth until the day closes. The server/chart time on any broker's MT4 platform will only agree with the local time in one time zone of the world. For example FXDD the default MT4 charts we use in this thread will not start a new day for another 2 hours and 15 minutes from the time of this post. Which is GMT +3. Until then the dot, along with the AC, AO, and Stoch may continue to change.

Boarder line on the daily chart the day ASHFX showed a buy signal.

This method just provides an option. Like any opportunity it is how it is handled by the one accepting or rejecting it. There are alot of considerations when looking at a setup on the Daily. So just blindly entering when the indicators meet the criteria... is like playing craps in the back alley. Use it to learn when not to trade and minimize risk. Next time before anyone claims the method sucks first evaluate what went into the thought process before during and when exiting the trade. You might find yourself evaluating your decisions and not being critical of the method. This self reflection can only make one a better trader in the long run. Both ASh Daily and Pipnailer are excellent tools but one must always be carefull when swinging that hammer.

What you're saying is probably true. I haven't lived long enough to go through such experiences.   
  
I agree that forex is a life-long learning experience. There's an old saying for this game I used to play:   
  
"It takes a minute to learn, but a lifetime to master".   
  
I see forex in the same light. It takes a relatively short time to learn the fundamentals of the market, a little longer to capitalize on those learned fundamentals, but it takes a lifetime to master it.   
  
I'll make the blind assumption that ChuckB is considerably older than I am (working age or thereabouts) and does not have as much time left as I do to invest in forex. It brings to mind another question: "What do you do with a dead horse?"  
  
Do you:

  1. Get a bigger whip
  2. Appoint a committee to ascertain the 'deadness' of the horse.
  3. Get off the horse

  1. Bucks
  2. Brains
  3. Balls

ChuckB seems to have the bucks and balls, but does he have the brains? Simply knowing the facts, text-book fundamentals and definitions is all good and well, but if you can't apply them, what use is it? I could read every textbook, forum, e-book, newsletter, vlog, newspaper, magazine, blog I want in an effort to become an actress (yes, ACTRESS). Does that mean I will achieve that goal? No. Does it make me stupid? No. Does it make me any worse than my neighbor? No. It simply means that I am not fit to be an actress. I may have more luck trying to become an actor, and that's what I'm suggesting for ChuckB.   
  
Forex may not be cut out for him, what about commodities? Derivatives? Stock? Real Estate? Futures? There are scores of other secuirities to trade.   
  
Ok, my rant is finished.

Among dozens of systems I have come across, this one is the simplest, easiest, most effective and reliable.   
  
No need to buy expensive "Black box" systems. No need to fret about complicated patterns, set ups or calculations. Just download Meta Trader Platform from FXDD (Live or Demo), and insert the prescribed indicators.  
  
No need to Sit in front of monitor all day, putting unnecessary stress on your blood pressure. From Sunday to Thursday, around 16.30 to 17.30 pm EST, just scan your favourite Pairs (or all the pairs available on FXDD) and note down the likely candidates for Full Strength as well as Secondary Strength potential Trades. Prefer Full Strength Trades and enter.  
  
Be patient. If there is no trade one day, don't push your luck. Wait for another day. Simply enter the trade, when all conditions are literally met and there is reasonable room for the pair to move in the direction of your trade (before price hits some major Support or Resistance).  
  
This routine of minimum effort, easy to follow system and simple discipline of not taking any "Weak" trades, will, in time, bring you impressive profits without too much heartache and panic attacks.  
  
Good Luck and Good Trading.

Hi All  
  
Xirtam. . .Here is the set file for EURCAD I am using ATM. . .  

Attached File(s)

![File Type: zip](https://assets.faireconomy.media/images/attach/zip.gif) [eurcad.zip](/attachment/file/155373?d=1223426714) < 1 KB | 360 downloads 

  
  
Regarding when to 'take your profit', I do not use the 'close on oppposite signal option'. I use TS and SL only, this is 'tailored' to each pair I am running. By using only a SL and TS I am only deciding how much to risk on each trade and NOT limiting the profit by using a set TP.  
  
No, I do not use previous candle to determine SL and TP for each pair. What I used when I set up this account is Average True Range (ATR). For each pair I included on each 4hr chart the ATR(100). I then used a SL and TS ABOUT 2 times the the 4hrATR(100). All other inputs for each pair is the same as the above preset file. When I originally setup the SL and TS I intended to redifine the TS and SL on a weekly basis but I have fallen behind on this intention. However I can say that I find most pairs will show up in the range of 150 to 250 pips range for the TP and SL.  
  
Thanks to Ash and RR for the great system and EA.

\- The AC has to be in favor of the trade   
\- The color of the reversal day bar has to be as well  
\- The AO can go either way, but I feel better if everything lines up.

Scott, if one was long, and the system signalled short, then one has a number of options. There are no hard & fast rules for AshFX Daily. One could either:  
  
a) Quit the long, and go short.  
  
b) Stay long, but go short as well (essentially hedging to an extent)  
  
c) Ignore the long signal, and stay short.  
  
d) Exit the long, and don't go short.  
  
Now, depending on the circumstances, EITHER ONE of those could be a good decision, especially the last one - remember, you don't have to always be in a trade. This is not a stop and reverse system.  
  
Having said that however, generally speaking, options a) and b) are the most viable.

I made a few trades on this system which I started using about a month ago. After a big hit I decided to start filtering the signals using 150 SMA and only taking trades according to the overall trend.  
  
**_Trading Record_**  
Second strength long EUR/GBP on 10/8/08 good for +365 pips. My first half was closed out at +365 pips and my stop that was set for breakeven was hit.  
  
Second strength long on 10/14/08 EUR/USD I was stopped out for -373 pips. I blindly followed the rules of the system and took a long signal in a massive downtrend which was against my better judgement.  
  
Second strength long on 10/14/08 CHF/JPY I was stopped out for -330 pips. Again, this long was against the trend and against my better judgement.   
  
After these two losses I decided that I would try to only take first strength trades following the trend due to the economic crisis around the world.  
  
11/03/08 - Long signal for USD/CHF. The 150 SMA was trending up and there was no major resistance so I took the long. I set the stop to the day's low at -282. I'm currently up +111 pips with a first target of 282.  
  
**_So over a month I took four trades_**  
Long EUR/GBP +362  
Long EUR/USD -373  
Long CHF/JPY -330  
Long USD/CHF +111 (still open, will be +282 if I win)  
  
So right now I am -230 pips over a month of trading.   
If I win the USD/CHF that is still open I will be at -59 pips.  
  
Keep in mind this is taking 2 second strength trades that were against the trend and my better judgement. I was impatient and couldn't wait to make trades which is why I took these signals and went long in a massive downtrend. If I had filtered these 2 signals with the 150SMA I would be +362 and +111 for a total of +473 at this time, +644 if I win the open USD/CHF.

I don't know why you said "in a timely manner". Your not paying for the system. People reply when they get around to it and if they want to.  
  
Note the name of the thread. It is a daily system as originally presented. If your friend has better results on a 15 minute chart you should talk to him and decide on your own how to trade the system. Some people have used it on a 4 hour chart.  
  
The system was originally tested on FXDD. That is the main reason to use FXDD for the signals. The other reason (in my mind) was so we could compare signals in the thread. If you like the system I would suggest running it on 3 MT4 platforms with different server times. Compare the results. Just because Ash originally tested and developed it on FXDD does not necessarly mean that is the best platform for the daily signal.  
  
FXDD's status with the regulators is harder to define. FXDD has a 'pending' status with the NFA. I don't know if they will complete. NFA ID: 0397435 if you want to go to the NFA site and look up the principals. [http://www.nfa.futures.org/basicnet/...d=0397435&rn=N](http://www.nfa.futures.org/basicnet/Details.aspx?entityid=0397435&rn=N)  
  
The important thing to remember is that you do not need to trade this system with a FXDD live account. You can use a demo FXDD account to get the daily signals and then use your broker of choice. One that you feel is safe, secure, and fair.

On viewing other trading systems i believe this thread would benifit a great deal with this indicator i am about to tell you about (due to the lack of time i am unable to provide pics ) it is known as centre of gravity also Arps Hurst Bands also Belkayate Bands. Basically they have a number of outter Bands and a central Middle Line , When prices reach these Outter bands there is meant to be 70% to 90% probability of bouncing back towards the middle line. Hence if we only trade at these pionts eg await for the price to touch them then await your Setup of AO,AC & Parabolic you should be in a more profitable trade.  
  
A discription of the Arps can be found at :  
  
[http://www.esignalcentral.com/univer...arps/hurst.asp](http://www.esignalcentral.com/university/esignal/addons/arps/hurst.asp)

Hope this can help some one out there.

I've tried out many, many systems (same as all the other 'would be traders' out there :-) and I always come back to this one because of its ease of use and its 'set and forget' characteristics. Must confess that I've found it somewhere else on the internet (without the stochastics, only the AC, AO and PSAR) and added a MACD to it. It's one of a few systems that seem to give consistent, longer term profits, although only since a couple of months; might have to do, for the bigger part, with my own improved trading abilities, but you should still give it a try.  
  
Before I open any trades, I look at correlated pairs and after getting some idea of overall trend I look for entries on the H4 charts (retracements - also use the MT4 Fibonacci retracements tool for this). Be aware of support/resistance area's on your charts (zoom out, as to view several days at the time) and don't get in too quick - don't be one of the herd, who gets tricked in to false breakouts by the market makers...). The 'round numbers' area's are of special importance too and I avoid getting into a trade when price hovers around them, up and down 20 or so pips.  
  
Don't know if you're new to trading, but thought I'd give this general advice for all new traders who might come across this thread...  
  
Cheers and good luck!
